fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.bodyText: • A feature in last Saturday’s Weekend magazine about Professor Tom Solomon, director of the Institute of Infection and Global Health at the University of Liverpool, quoted him as saying that Pauline Cafferkey, the British nurse who contracted Ebola in west Africa, worked for Médecins sans Frontières. In fact she worked at a Save the Children treatment centre in Sierra Leone (Going viral, page 32). • In a piece about the singer-songwriter Prince (Hidden 4 U, 20 March, page 10, G2), we stated inconclusively that “the story goes that if [he] were to leave the world tomorrow, he has enough unreleased material to put out an album a year”. An album a year for how long, some readers reasonably asked. Until sometime in the 22nd century, we ought to have said. A typo later in the piece – the omission of an S – had us referring to some of Prince’s “closet collaborators”. • St Clement Danes school was in East Acton when Andy Fraser was expelled from it for refusing to wear his hair short, not in Chorleywood, Hertfordshire, as we had it in our obituary of the bass player and songwriter with the British blues-rock band Free (19 March, page 41). The school moved to the latter location in 1975. • Other recently corrected articles include: To understand the pyramids and Stonehenge, look up – not down Ecuador’s radical grammar pedants on a mission to correctly punctuate graffiti Florida employee ‘punished for using phrase climate change’ Bill Cosby accuser backs Nevada bill to lift statute of limitations on sex crimes Shaw Taylor obituary The Secret Diary of Adrian Mole Aged 13¾ review – quaint, charming musical
